docs.lead_paragraph: In 2000, Gloria Mark was hired as a professor at the University of California at Irvine. Until then, she was working as a researcher, living a life of comparative peace. She would spend her days in her lab, enjoying the sense of serene focus that comes from immersing yourself for hours at a time in a single project. But when her faculty job began, that all ended. Mark would arrive at her desk in the morning, full of energy and ready to tackle her to-do list -- only to suffer an endless stream of interruptions. No sooner had she started one task than a colleague would e-mail her with an urgent request; when she went to work on that, the phone would ring. At the end of the day, she had been so constantly distracted that she would have accomplished only a fraction of what she set out to do. ''Madness,'' she thought. ''I'm trying to do 30 things at once.''

docs.lead_paragraph: CORPORATE leaders need to improve the international image of the United States because their companies' futures are increasingly at stake, says Keith Reinhard, president of Business for Diplomatic Action and chairman of the advertising agency DDB Worldwide. Here are excerpts from a conversation: Q. Which American business sectors are feeling the effects of a poor international image? A. Inbound travel from other countries is off at least 1.5 percent, in terms of market share, from 2000 levels. One share point is 7.6 million visits and $12 billion in sales, because people who visit from other countries tend to stay longer and spend more. That's the equivalent of 153,000 jobs and lots of tax dollars. Q. Which chief executives are feeling that impact? A. No C.E.O. is willing to say the bottom line is hurting. But we have research that shows intention. For example, we know that 37 percent of the British intelligentsia say they will avoid buying U.S. brands because of the ''cultural identity'' of the United States. We know that in Group of 8 countries, 18 percent of the population claim they are avoiding American brands, with the top brand being Marlboro in terms of avoidance. Barbie is another one. McDonald's is another. There is a cooling toward American culture generally across the globe. Q. Is the war in Iraq driving the negativity? A. That's one of four root causes. Another is the arrogance, ignorance and insensitivity of American people. A third reason for anti-American sentiment is the pervasiveness of American pop culture. We're not the only source of ''cool'' anymore. And the fourth reason is the effects of globalization. In developing countries, they resent the fact that American-led globalization has, in their minds, left them out.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is a techie adage that goes like this: In China or Japan the nail that stands up gets hammered, while in Silicon Valley the nail that stands up drives a Ferrari and has stock options. Underlying that adage is a certain American confidence that whatever we lack in preparing our kids with strong fundamentals in math and science, we make up for by encouraging our best students to be independent, creative thinkers. There is a lot of truth to that. Even the Chinese will tell you that they've been good at making the next new thing, and copying the next new thing, but not imagining the next new thing. Confident that its best K-12 students will usually outperform America's in math and science, China is focusing on how to transform its classrooms so students become more innovative.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN James E. West was 8 years old, he propped himself on his bed's brass footboard one afternoon and stretched to plug the cord of a radio he had repaired into a ceiling outlet. It was one of his first experiments. Mr. West's hand sealed to the light socket as 120 volts of electricity shimmied through his body, freezing him in place until his brother knocked him from the footboard and onto the floor. Like more storied inventors who preceded him, he was quickly hooked on the juice -- even as he lay shivering from that first encounter. ''I became fascinated by electricity after that, just completely fascinated,'' recalled Mr. West, now 74 and an award-winning research professor at Johns Hopkins University. ''I needed to learn everything I could about it.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The newest expatriates aren't people. They're ideas, and we can't afford to watch them go. The Wall Street Journal reported last week that Microsoft had trimmed more than $500 million from its annual tax bill by putting a small subsidiary in Dublin in charge of $16 billion in assets. The game is simple: a company sends intellectual property to a tax-haven country like Ireland and keeps the tax difference on the money it earns. The world is used to seeing manufacturing businesses move to countries where labor is cheaper, like Mexico or China. But profits from software created and designed at Microsoft's headquarters, in Redmond, Wash., should be taxed in America, not Ireland. Unfortunately, outsourcing is extending itself to taxes, in large part because the United States Congress has given businesses the loopholes to do it. That means that America's greatest asset -- its intellectual property -- could be sent offshore to reduce corporate tax burdens.

docs.lead_paragraph: TIVO TAKEOUT The News -- On Monday, TiVo, the maker of digital video recorders, announced that its subscribers will be able to transfer recorded television programs onto their Apple video iPods and Sony handheld PSP game machines. The new service builds on the company's TiVo to Go feature, which allows some subscribers to transfer shows to a laptop or personal computer. Behind the News -- The television networks have yet another reason to hate TiVo, which first encroached on their turf by offering viewers the ability to watch television shows when they wanted, without the commercials. Now, TiVo could hurt the networks' attempts to develop another revenue stream by selling shows by the episode. For instance, ABC plans to sell downloads of ''Desperate Housewives'' on Apple iPods for 99 cents. But why pay, when you can download from TiVo for free? X-GAMES BEGIN The News -- Microsoft released its Xbox 360, its next-generation game machine, at midnight on Tuesday. Buyers lined up for hours to be among the first to purchase it. Behind the News -- Industry analysts said the early buzz around the Xbox 360 might not mean much in the long run. The real question is whether the 360 can outsell Sony's next-generation game console, PlayStation 3, which is not due out until spring. LIBRARY DOWNLOAD The News -- Google gave $3 million to help the Library of Congress build a World Digital Library on the Web. For the project, the National Library of Egypt has already agreed to digitize documents of Islamic science from the 10th century. Behind the News -- Google's gift may be good public relations. The Library of Congress emphasized that Google's gift comes with no strings attached and no copyright problems. That would be welcome news for Google, which has faced copyright issues because of its Book Search project, a book- scanning effort in partnership with five research libraries. GOODNIGHT, TED The News -- On Tuesday, Ted Koppel, the anchor of ''Nightline'' ended his 25-year reign as late night's Mr. Serious. Behind the News -- Will ''Nightline'' survive? Under Mr. Koppel, it has struggled in the ratings, generally falling behind NBC's ''The Tonight Show With Jay Leno'' and CBS's ''Late Show With David Letterman.'' Now, three anchors will replace Mr. Koppel, and it's unknown how quickly ABC expects ratings success.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR decades, first on radio and then on television, the phrases ''And now a word from our sponsor'' and ''Brought to you by '' were as commonplace as canned laughter. Shows even saluted their advertiser patrons by name, from ''The Bell Telephone Hour'' to ''Magnavox Theater'' to ''Westinghouse Desilu Playhouse.'' But by the late 1950's, rising costs along with concerns about control over programming produced profound change. Advertisers shifted from sole sponsorships to buying commercials one spot at a time all over the network schedules. docs.lead_paragraph: Q. You work for a good friend, but lately you've begun to have doubts about his business judgment. Is there a way to handle this without ruining the friendship? A. Nobody enjoys unpleasant discussions with friends, but your job requires that you put the interests of the company first, said Michael Gibbs, clinical professor of economics and human resources at the University of Chicago. ''Friendship is important, but at the end of the day, your top priority at work has to be the business itself,'' he said. ''When you start losing faith in your boss's ability to perform on the job, it's time to speak up.'' Q. Was it wise to agree to work for a friend in the first place? A. It's late in the game to question your decision, but it's worth remembering that mixing personal and professional lives can be tricky. Sure, it can be fun to work with people you know and respect. And when it works out over the long run, it can be very rewarding to share passion for a mission with pals you've known for years. Bill Gates and Steve Ballmer, for example, were roommates in college, joined forces at Microsoft in 1980 and still work together today. Even if the two quarrel behind the scenes, the relationship evidently works.

headline.main: When a Friend Is Also Your Boss

During his tenure as the European Union competition watchdog, Mr. Monti was known for taking a tough line. He threatened to derail America Online's acquisition of Time Warner in 2000 and pursued a monopoly investigation into Microsoft. In 2001, Mr. Monti blocked General Electric's proposed merger with Honeywell International, the first time European regulators had killed a merger approved by their counterparts in the United States. Mr. Monti is president of Bocconi University in Milan and chairman of Bruegel, a research group based in Brussels.

docs.lead_paragraph: COMPETITION IN REGISTERED TRAVEL -- There is growing competition in the nascent Registered Travel program that enables passengers to move more quickly through airport security. The program is run by private companies under federal supervision, and passengers pay a fee to be prescreened to get a biometric encoded identification card, which uses fingerprints and iris scans. Right now, the only operating program is called Clear, run at the airport in Orlando, Fla., by Verified Identity Pass of New York. Yesterday, the Saflink Corporation, a security company based in Bellevue, Wash., said it had expanded a partnership that now includes Microsoft to compete in the Registered Traveler program. Other partners include Johnson Controls., Expedia Corporate Travel and ID Technology Partners. The Transportation Security Administration has said a wide rollout of the program beyond Orlando would begin next year at airports nationally. At Orlando, more than 11,000 frequent fliers have already signed up for Clear, which costs $79.95 a year, the company's founder, Steven Brill, said. Saflink, in announcing yesterday that it had expanded its partnership, said its competing card could also be used as a credit card. A COURTYARD FOR MOSCOW -- The first Courtyard by Marriott hotel in Russia is scheduled to open this week with rooms ''offering spectacular views of the Kremlin,'' Marriott International says. The opening of the 218-room hotel will expand to 100,000 the number of guest rooms within Courtyard, Marriott's main moderately priced brand, which operates 700 hotels in the United States and abroad. Introductory rates at the Moscow Courtyard will start at $225 plus tax, the company said. FOR BETTER ONLINE BOOKING -- More than 80 percent of small-business travelers book trips directly on airline Web sites, but they are not especially impressed with the sites' flexibility, a new survey by the American Small Business Travelers Alliance, a nonprofit organization based in Flower Mound, Tex., finds. ''The Internet has done much to level the playing field for small-business travelers,'' Chet Gray, the vice president of the group, said in a statement. Small businesses, including the self-employed, do not typically have access to in-house booking systems used by big companies to arrange travel. While the survey shows small-business travelers are avidly booking online directly with airlines, ''opportunities remain for more tailored services on these sites,'' Mr. Gray said. ONE THICK MAGAZINE -- A new in-flight magazine, US Airways Magazine, with its first issue in January weighing in at a fat 200-plus pages, is being published by Pace Communications, which also puts out United Airlines' Hemispheres and Delta Air Lines' Sky magazines. US Airways Magazine, with a monthly printing of 375,000 copies, will replace America West Magazine and US Airways' Attaché magazine, and will be available on all flights flown by the merged carriers and their regional partners. LEARN FRENCH WHILE YOU FLY -- Travelers on Singapore Airlines can now take interactive language-learning lessons in 20 different languages on the airlines' in-flight on-demand entertainment system. That doubles the number of language offerings available since the program began in June, the airline said. The programs are produced by Berlitz World Traveler. In all, Singapore's in-flight entertainment system, which it calls KrisWorld, has more than 500 on-demand video and audio options, including 60 movies. QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS -- A reader was asked the following at a check-in counter at the airport in Birmingham, Ala.: ''Has anyone put anything in your baggage without your knowledge?'' The reader's reply: ''If it was without my knowledge, how would I know?''

docs.lead_paragraph: Outlook Express And Viruses Q. I use Outlook Express for e-mail. Does that window at the bottom that shows the selected message make me more vulnerable to computer viruses? A. Outlook Express has had its share of security problems over the years, and there have been malicious threats that take advantage of its preview pane, which displays the contents of a message without your having to open the file. Internet security experts have often recommended turning off the preview pane to prevent such instant virus and worm infections when you go through your e-mail. You can turn off the preview pane by going to the Views menu in Outlook Express, selecting the Layout option and unchecking the box next to ''Show preview pane.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Users of Google's search engine will soon see something they are not used to on the notoriously spare site: advertising with logos and graphics. And the advertisers will not be limited to America Online, whose talks with Google prompted the change in policy, according to two executives close to the companies' negotiations. As part of their deal, which is expected to be formally announced this afternoon, Google is providing AOL with $300 million worth of advertising on Google's Web sites, intended to use to draw Google search users to related content on AOL's sites, the executives said. That sum is on top of the $1 billion in cash that Google is to invest to buy a 5 percent stake in AOL.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wall Street's hopes of prolonging its year-end rally were set back yesterday as cautious traders sold stocks and the technology sector posted a steep decline. The market opened little changed but turned lower at midday despite a court victory for Pfizer and a multibillion-dollar acquisition by the FPL Group. The investment by Google in America Online and strong earnings from Circuit City Stores were unable to lift tech shares, which have fallen sharply in recent days.

docs.lead_paragraph: Electronic Arts, a bellwether company among video game makers, reported on Tuesday that its holiday sales would be ''well below'' earlier projections, the latest sign of a sharp slide in performance for the industry. The announcement from Electronic Arts, the largest independent game publisher, came less than a week after Activision, a competitor, also reported unexpectedly weak holiday sales. NPD, a market research company, reported last week that video game software sales were down 18 percent last month from November 2004.

byline.original: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and JENNY ANDERSON; Diana B. Henriques contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: STRIKING transit workers may have brought subways and buses to a stop in New York this week, but the news kept flowing. Much of it was driven by the time of year, as corporate chiefs and government officials scrambled to tidy up things before the new year. A MOGUL IS BORN -- Ending a succession story that was never much of a mystery, Time Warner named Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the head of its movie and television businesses, as its president and chief operating officer. The promotion makes him heir apparent to the chairman and chief executive, Richard D. Parsons. Mr. Bewkes, 53, was one of two lieutenants to Mr. Parsons, 57. The other, Don Logan, 61, who heads Time Warner's publishing, cable and online properties, will retire at the end of the year and become nonexecutive chairman of the company's cable business. Mr. Bewkes is perhaps best known for his time at HBO, where he made his mark -- and HBO's reputation -- with hit programs like ''The Sopranos'' and ''Sex and the City.'' In an interview, Mr. Bewkes said he did not anticipate any immediate executive changes. That may be because he will be busy fending off a campaign by the financier Carl C. Icahn to make major changes at the company to raise its stock price. LUNCH TAB -- A California jury ordered Wal-Mart Stores to pay $172 million in damages for failing to provide meal breaks to nearly 116,000 hourly workers as required under state law. The suit, filed on behalf of employees of Wal-Mart and Sam's Club stores in California, argued that the chain violated state law more than eight million times. California law requires that employers provide a meal break of 30 minutes for every five hours on the clock. If the break is shorter than that, provided late or not at all, the employer must pay an hour's pay. Wal-Mart, which faces similar cases in about 40 other states, said it planned to appeal. LATEST INDICTMENT -- Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, the dominant local phone company in 14 Western states, was indicted for selling more than $100 million worth of stock in his company in 2001 after learning that it would miss its financial goals but before making that news public. In a separate action in March, the Securities and Exchange Commission sued Mr. Nacchio and other former executives, accusing them of overstating $3 billion in revenue from 1999 to 2002. It said the inflated figures helped Mr. Nacchio earn $216 million in pay and bonuses. In court, he pleaded not guilty. Several other former Qwest executives have already pleaded guilty and cooperated with government investigators. Qwest agreed last month to pay $400 million to investors hurt by the false financial statements. It also agreed to pay $250 million in fines to the S.E.C. last year. Prosecutors and the defense team are scheduled to meet on Jan. 20 in federal court in Denver, where Qwest is based, to set a timetable for the trial. PULLING THE PLUG -- Burdened with debts used to build power plants and with long-term contracts obligating it to sell electricity below the cost of making it, Calpine, a symbol of market deregulation, filed for bankruptcy protection. Calpine was hurt by the California energy crisis, which sent prices soaring after the company locked itself into long-term contracts, and by the collapse of Enron, which provided much of the liquidity in electricity-trading markets. Calpine, which employs 3,300 people, has $2 billion of debtor-in-possession financing, which is enough to keep its plants operating for now. But creditors are maneuvering to seize its assets, which include one of the world's largest geothermal plants, in Northern California. POWER GRAB -- In one of the largest takeovers in the electricity industry, the FPL Group agreed to buy Constellation Energy for $11 billion, creating a company that will own the nation's largest portfolio of electricity generation assets, with more than 45,000 megawatts of capacity. The combined company will have revenue of about $27 billion and will be the third-largest provider of nuclear-fueled electricity and one of the largest operators of coal-fired power plants. More mergers are likely after February, when the federal government repeals legislation that prevents conglomerates from using power monopolies to overcharge customers and subsidize other businesses. A DEAL, SORT OF -- Trade ministers from around the world agreed to stop subsidizing agricultural exports by 2013 and took steps to make it easier for the poorest nations to sell goods to industrialized nations. But the talks, held in Hong Kong under the guidance of the World Trade Organization, did little to persuade rich countries to lower import tariffs or limit subsidies to their own farmers and ranchers. The agreement helps negotiators as they try to finish a comprehensive set of trade rules by the end of 2007, in time for President Bush to submit it to Congress before a Congressional deadline expires. GAME OVER? -- Electronic Arts, the largest independent game publisher, and Activision, a big competitor, said holiday sales of their computer and video games were unexpectedly weak. NPD, a market research company, said domestic game sales fell 18 percent last month, to $700 million, from November a year ago. Paradoxically, a big reason for the slowdown may be the success of the Microsoft Xbox 360 console. Because Microsoft did not make enough to satisfy demand, consumers waiting to buy an Xbox 360 may have stopped buying games for other consoles, like the original Xbox and the Sony PlayStation 2. The slump may be reversed next year, when more Xbox 360's are in the hands of consumers and after Sony, the leading console maker, and Nintendo release new versions of their hardware. MOST VIEWED -- Following are the most-viewed articles from Dec. 17 to Dec. 23: 1. Governments Tremble at Google's Bird's-Eye View 2. Notebooks Come In at Under a Thousand With Speed and Style 3. Health Care for All, Just a (Big) Step Away 4. Transition to Digital Gets Closer 5. That Blur? It's China, Moving Up in the Pack Links are at nytimes.com/business.

docs.lead_paragraph: The war for control of the next-generation DVD is approaching a critical juncture: next week in Las Vegas at the Consumer Electronics Show, companies championing the two competing high-definition DVD standards -- Blu-ray and HD-DVD -- will unveil their lineups of new players and movie titles. There are growing signs, though, that the battle for supremacy in this multibillion-dollar market may yield a hollow victory. As electronics makers, technology companies and Hollywood studios haggle over the fine points of their formats, consumers are quickly finding alternatives to buying and renting packaged DVD's, high definition or otherwise.

headline.main: Fiddling With Format While DVD's Burn; The Fight Over the Next Standard May Be Eclipsed by Other Technology

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. One of your co-workers loves to chat, and whenever he isn't dealing with a pressing deadline, he barges into your work space to shoot the breeze. How do you restore peace and quiet? A. As tempted as you may be to tell the office chatterbox to scram, it's best to approach this grating situation with tact, said Gini Graham Scott, president of Changemakers, a consulting firm in Oakland, Calif. ''Be as diplomatic as possible,'' said Ms. Scott, the author of ''A Survival Guide for Working with Bad Bosses'' (Amacom, 2005). ''Try to show respect and compassion for the other person when you do this, but if the person doesn't get the hint, then you have to be firm.'' Q. What drives certain co-workers to talk excessively? A. Whether the topic is ''Desperate Housewives'' or the conflict in Iraq, everybody likes to chat at work from time to time. But some people simply do not know when to stop. According to Cheryl A. Dellasega, professor of humanities at the Pennsylvania State University College of Medicine in Hershey, many chatterboxes are procrastinators who use banter to avoid the tasks at hand. Sometimes anxiety, nervousness or loneliness can make a person prone to chattering. In rare cases, she said, excessive talking can be a form of hostility.

headline.main: How to Shush The Office Magpie

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN she was growing up in a New York City housing project, Stacy Abrego says, she thought that highly skilled professionals were ''uppity.'' And she had no reason to change that view while holding a series of ''little jobs here and there'' into her mid-20's, she says. But she was proved wrong a year and a half ago, she says, by an organization that uses volunteers from the ranks of corporate professionals to train and serve as mentors to low-income people for office jobs and then helps them seek new jobs. The nonprofit organization, StreetWise Partners, has guided her onto a career track that is more financially and psychologically rewarding than her previous path, Ms. Abrego, 27, said recently after a day's work as an administrative assistant at the United Way of New York City.

headline.main: From Anti-'Uppity' to Upwardly Mobile

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 2001, the stock market meltdown and a brief recession threw cold water on the widely held belief that the United States economy, juiced by a technological revolution, had entered a new era of limitless, inflation-free growth. But today, as bubble-era books like ''Dow 36,000'' collect dust on library shelves, evidence is mounting that there may be a new economy after all. In the late 1990's, growth in labor productivity -- the amount of output per hour per worker -- kicked into a higher gear. From 1996 through 1999, it grew at a blistering annual rate of 2.5 percent, compared with 1.4 percent from 1972 to 1995. Economists generally believed that the higher rate was a byproduct of the new economy. Much of the growth was spurred by the highly productive businesses that made information technology products -- companies like Dell, Intel and Microsoft -- and by their customers, who spent heavily to deploy productivity-enhancing PC's and software.

headline.main: What Makes a Nation More Productive? It's Not Just Technology
